conclusion: The lamp is high, to the left of the group and a little in front of it.
The lamp moves forward above the objects, keeping the same height but sliding deeper into the scene (away from the viewer, still on the left).
The horizontal distance from the lamp to every object increases.
The light strikes each object at a shallower (more grazing) angle.
The direction of the horizontal component of the light hardly changes (still comes from the left), but its forward/backward component grows.
Every shadow’s center shifts farther away from the lamp, i.e., farther down the picture and a little more toward the viewer.
Because the rays are now more oblique, every shadow becomes longer/larger.
The taller the object, the larger the percentage increase in shadow size.
Object A is a pie on a plate, a low object.
Object A’s shadow slides a small distance further down/right, and its diameter grows only a little; the outline stays round/oval.
Object B is a desk calendar, a medium-height object.

Object B’s shadow moves the same general way as A but farther, because the object is taller. The length of the rectangular patch increases noticeably; the calendar’s top edge projects farther from its feet.
Object C is a milk carton, the tallest of the four objects.
Object C experiences the greatest shift. Its shadow stretches markedly; its tip can reach well beyond its present end.
Object D is a baseball, a very low object.
Object D’s shadow shift is comparable to A but slightly more because the lamp’s forward motion affects everything. The outline remains circular, just a little larger.
When the light source is pushed forward above the group, every shadow (A, B, C, D) slides farther down-and-to-the-right and all of them grow.
The amount of growth follows the objects’ heights: C grows and shifts the most, B next, then A and D, which are the shortest and change the least.
